flags.title: User-Contributed Project
flags.text: This project guide is not managed by MAKE staff.

guide.introduction:
I will break down each costume for easier reading. The Boo Berry was probably the most labor intensive so I'll start there.

I paper mache'd a complete helmet using a large balloon and flour paste. It took 36 hours to completely dry but I wanted it sturdy so I used several layers. Once dry i painted it white using several coats. We cut the eyes out. I glued a fleece blanket on the top, allowing the fabric to drape. I also airbrushed the fleece with a light blue. I stretched the fabric tightly over the face and cut an X and glued the fabric around the eyes hole. Using two 3" circles with smaller circles cut out I glued around the eyes and cut a blue circle in half for the eyelids. i re-used an old easter hat yellow with a red band and glued that on top. Easy enough, huh?

Frankenberry and Count Chocula are basic paper mache masks. I cut to shape and painted to look like the characters the best i could. Frankenberry does have a pressure gauge on his right side which was a kabob stick broken and taped with silver duct tape, the gauge itself was printed offline and glued into the bottom of a clear fruit cup I had cut to 1/4" deep. The other side of Frankenberry has a steam vent that is made out of a ketchup sqeezee bottle painted pink with a pink paper cone glued on top.

This was so much fun to make!

guide.summary: Here you will find out how I made the cereal monsters: Franken Berry, Count Chocula and Boo Berry. The 3 Halloween costumes my family made and wore. They are not professional nor perfect but they were a blast to make. The cost of making all 3 was under $1
guide.time_required: 2 days for paper mache to dry, 2 hours for rest
